p: Carvacrol is the most important biologically active phenolic compound in the essential oil of the two cultivated Satureja species [ 100, 101, 110] and is responsible for their significant antioxidant activity [ 101, 111]. These species are the richest sources of carvacrol in the Lamiaceae. In addition to peppermint, carvacrol has also been identified in plant species of the Chenopodiaceae, Plantaginaceae, Apiaceae, and Verbenaceae [ 110]. This phenolic compound also inhibits prostaglandin biosynthesis, which is an important mechanism in relieving pain and anti-inflammatory processes. Other reported biological activities of carvacrol are antispasmodic, inhibition of acetylcholinesterase, lipid peroxidation, free radical scavenging, and macrophage stimulation of white blood cells [ 112].
